should.translation[0].definitions[0].def: used to say what is the right or sensible thing to do
should.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Children shouldn’t be allowed to play in the street.
‘I don’t care what people think.’ ‘Well, you should.’
Why shouldn’t I smoke if I want to?
should.translation[0].definitions[1].def: used to say what would have been right or sensible, but was not done
should.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: They should have called the police.
should.translation[0].definitions[2].def: used to give or ask for advice
should.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: You should read his new book.
I should stay in bed if I were you.
should.translation[0].definitions[3].def: used to say that you expect something to happen or be true
should.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: It should be a nice day tomorrow.
Try phoning Robert – he should be home by now.
‘Artistic people can be very difficult sometimes.’ ‘Well, you should know – you married one.’
should.translation[0].definitions[4].def: used to say what was expected, but did not happen
should.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: It was an easy test and he should have passed, but he didn’t.
should.translation[0].definitions[5].def: used to say what is the correct amount, the correct way of doing something etc
should.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: Every sentence should start with a capital letter.
What do you mean, there are only ten tickets? There should be twelve.
White wine, not red, should be served with fish.
should.translation[0].definitions[6].def: used in official orders and instructions
should.translation[0].definitions[7].def: used in a clause beginning with ‘that’ after particular adjectives and verbs
should.translation[0].definitions[7].exa: It’s strange that you should say that.
It is essential that he should have a fair trial.
The residents demanded that there should be an official inquiry.
should.translation[0].definitions[8].def: used to talk about something that may possibly happen or be true
should.translation[0].definitions[8].exa: Naturally, he was nervous in case anything should go wrong.
What if I should fall sick and not be able to work?
Should you need any help  (=if you need any help), you can always phone me at the office.
should.translation[0].definitions[9].def: used after ‘I’ or ‘we’ to say what you would do if something happened or was true
should.translation[0].definitions[9].exa: If anyone treated me like that, I should complain to the manager.
I should be surprised if many people voted for him.
should.translation[0].definitions[10].de: used to politely ask for something, offer to do something, or say that you want to do something
should.translation[0].definitions[10].ex: I should be grateful if you could provide me with some information.
‘What can I get you?’ ‘I should like a long cool drink.’
We should be delighted to help in any way we can.
I should like to thank you all for coming here tonight.
should.translation[0].definitions[11].de: used as the past tense of ‘shall’ after ‘I’ or ‘we’ to say what you intended or expected to do
should.translation[0].definitions[11].ex: We knew that we should be leaving the next day.
